results.title: The Gift
results.brief_description: Deanna is given a real gift in life, this gift is really challenging but as she begins to understand the nature of this gift she understands its true importance.

results.title: The Giants
results.creator_credit: Zdenka Deitchova, Kratky Film and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: A satirical cartoon film which exposes and ridicules in allegorical form, human intolerance, malice, cowardice and irresponsibility. Intended as a protest against violence and despotism.

results.title: The Giant radio telescope
results.brief_description: A. C. B. Lovell (professor of radio astronomy, University of Manchester) is interviewed about the new giant radio telescope at Jodrell Bank. This historic film was shot in the early years of radio astronomy and the Jodrell Bank telescope was one of the most advanced of its kind. Lovell would later play a key figure in the space race over the next few years, aiding the Soviet Union in tracking cosmonaughtical space programs.

results.title: The Ghost train
results.creator_credit: Edward Black, Gainsborough Pictures, Gaumont and Walter Forde
results.brief_description: Tales of ghosts and things that go bump in the night feature in this British comedy thriller about a phantom train and a group of travellers stranded overnight in the waiting room of a small Cornish junction station. Stars Arthur Askey along with Richard Murdoch, Kathleen Harrison, Peter Murray-Hill, Carole Lynne and Morland Graham. Based on the play by Arnold Ridley.

results.title: The Ghost paintings
results.brief_description: An innovative Melbourne artist, James Clayden has worked in theatre, film and painting for more than 30 years. His ‘Ghost Paintings’ series, produced over the past seventeen years, represents a bold and unique synthesis of film and video art. By combining cryptic fragments of dialogue delivered by actors, with highly saturated unfocused images and a disorienting soundscape, he creates an abstracted visual poetry that defies rational analysis, but that nevertheless invokes thought in the viewer. Cast: Helen Hopkins, Tom Wright, Faruk Avdi, Shelley Lasica, Meg White, Thomas Eckersley. Music: Ad Hoc, The Other (Chris Knowles, David Wadelton, David Brown, James Clayden).

results.title: The Ghost camera. The Last journey
results.creator_credit: Julius Hagen, Twickenham Films Studios and Bernard Vorhaus
results.brief_description: ‘Quota quickies’ (B movies shot fast on low budgets), provided excellent training ground for young talent in the early years of cinema. Vorhaus thrived on the breakneck economies of the quickie world and informal atmosphere of Twickenham Studios, making the most of the exceptional creative freedom allowed to anyone who could bring the pictures in on time and on budget. ‘The Ghost Camera’, a murder mystery was edited by David Lean. It marks the beginning of Vorhaus’ association with Twickenham Studios. The film announces to the world a director with ideas of his own by kicking off with what may well be the first-ever pre-credit sequence. And it does exactly what a good pre-credit sequence should do: sets up the premise of the film, establishes the mood and piques our curiosity. It is worth recalling that 1933 audiences would most likely have had no advance knowledge of what they were about to see. Few people would trouble to enquire about the supporting feature beforehand, and might not even notice the title. By boldly setting up the mystery in this way, Vorhaus hoped to hold his audience’s attention through an hour or so of Fowler Mear’s lumbering banter. Cast includes Henry Kendall, Ida Lupino and John Mills. Unlike most British feature film-makers of the Thirties whose work, whether high - or low-budget, tended to be studio-bound, Vorhaus loved to shoot on location whenever possible, lending his films an engaging freshness and immediacy. ‘The Last Journey’ is the film that showcases Vorhaus’s distinctive qualities - the inventive narrative style, the instinct for composition and the incisive wit of his editing - to best advantage. A multiple-story train thriller in the tradition of ‘Rome Express’ (1932) and the later ‘The Lady Vanishes’ (1938), it stands comparison with either (despite their far larger budgets) thanks to its pace and whip-crack editing. No risible Hornby-Double-O model shots, either: the trains are very much for real. Given the central storyline (an express train in the grip of a deranged driver hurtles westward towards the ultimate buffers) one might expect the rail companies to be less than enthused, but the Great Western Railway provided full co-operation. ‘They didn’t ask what the story was,’ Vorhaus recalls, ‘and we didn’t tell them.’ Three sequences in particular display the powerdrive cutting technique that Vorhaus brought to action scenes. During its runaway course, the train twice barrels at full lick through a station where it is supposed to stop, to the alarm of the passengers and railway official alike. Two such episodes could have been repetitious; but by varying his camera angles and tossing in lighting gags and character vignettes Vorhaus neatly differentiates them. Cast includes Hugh Williams, Godfrey Tearle, Julien Mitchell, and Judy Gunn. Reference: Adapted from the notes supplied by Philip Kemp.

results.title: The Ghost and Mrs. Muir
results.creator_credit: Fred Kohlmar, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Joseph L Mankiewicz
results.brief_description: Lucy Muir (Gene Tierney) a beautiful widow and her daughter (Natalie Wood) rent a house by the ocean, and refuse to be frightened by the former owner’s ghost, a dashing sea captain (Rex Harrison). When her income suddenly stops, he suggests that they collaborate on a book about his life and the unlikely pair fall deeply in love. Then Lucy’s affection is challenged by a live man (George Sanders), leaving the broken-hearted captain to choose another course. Acclaimed for its heartwarming screenplay and Oscar-nominated cinematography, this film is a moving, sentimental Hollywood classic.

results.title: The Ghan: a spiritual connection
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
The legendary Ghan was named after the Afghans who with their camels opened the supply line through Australia’s interior. On this rich and fascinating journey from Adelaide to the Red Centre of Australia, traverse some of the world’s most ancient and inhospitable terrain, exploring the history of this great train line. At the remote town of Pimba, attend a rock concert in the middle of the Australian desert, arranged by the world music organisation WOMAD. Later, when the Ghan pulls into Alice Springs, visit Uluru, the largest free standing rock in the world. Uluru is a sacred aboriginal dreaming site that was returned to it’s original owners in 1985 and is now one of Australia’s most celebrated tourist attractions.

results.title: The Getting of Wisdom [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Phillip Adams, Southern Cross Film Productions and Bruce Beresford
results.brief_description: Laura Tweedle Ramsbotham is about to enter another world. From her home in sleepy, rural Australia she ascends to the dreaming spires of an exclusive college for young ladies, a very strict Victorian boarding school in Melbourne. Laura (Susannah Fowles) is strong willed and rebellious, which creates conflict with her peers and her teachers. In a desperate attempt to find acceptance with her peers, she weaves the most lurid yarns imaginable. The only real soulmate she finds is one of the senior girls. This novel by Henry Handel Richardson was published in 1910, and was so shocking at the time that the author’s name (Ethel Richardson) was stricken from the records of the school in which she set the thinly-disguised autobiography. An amusing and sometimes touching story which features an excellent performance from Barry Humphries as the repressed fire and brimstone minister. Also stars John Waters, Sheila Helpman, Patricia Kennedy and Julie Blake.
